column2: CHAPTER II
column3: CHAPTER two

column2: We leave Missouri and go South--The prisoners of Donelson--The taking of New Madrid--"Kindly bury this unfortunate officer"--Quaker guns at Shiloh--The killing of the colonel.
column3: We leave Missouri and go South-The prisoners of Donelson-The taking of New Madrid-"Kindly bury this unfortunate officer"--Quaker guns at Shiloh-The killing of the colonel.

column2: It was a trifling incident, this capture, compared with the dreadful things I have referred to as going on in Missouri that memorable first year of the Civil War.
column3: It was a trifling incident, this capture, compared with the dreadful things I have referred to as going on in Missouri that memorable first year of the Civil War.

column2: A great volume would not contain the record of them all.
column3: A great volume would not contain the record of them all.

column2: The first dead men I saw while in the army were eight Missouri farmers murdered by guerrillas and left lying in the hot sun and dust at the roadside.
column3: The first dead men I saw while in the army were eight Missouri farmers murdered by guerrillas and left lying in the hot sun and dust at the roadside.

column2: The sight moved me as no great battle ever did afterward.
column3: The sight moved me as no great battle ever did afterward.

column2: One half of the male population of Missouri was trying to kill the other half.
column3: One half of the male population of Missouri was trying to kill the other half.

column2: They were not opponents from different far-off sections fighting, but near neighbors, and nothing seemed too awful or too cruel for them to do.
column3: They were not opponents from different far off sections fighting, but near neighbors, and nothing seemed too awful or too cruel for them to do.

column2: How I pitied the women and children who lived in the State in those awful days!
column3: How I pitied the women and children who lived in the State in those awful days!

column2: General Sherman's designation of war as "hell" found more confirmation in the dreadful raids, outrages, and murders by Quantrell's guerrillas in Missouri than in the bloodiest battles of the four years' conflict.
column3: General Sherman's designation of war as "hell" found more confirmation in the dreadful raids, outrages, and murders by Quantrell's guerrillas in Missouri than in the bloodiest battles of the four years' conflict.

column2: Now for months my regiment, with others, had chased up and down, and all over that unhappy old State of Missouri, trying to capture and punish these bands of murderers.
column3: Now for months my regiment, with others, had chased up and down, and all over that unhappy old State of Missouri, trying to capture and punish these bands of murderers.

column2: On the old steamboat _War Eagle_, too, we paddled for weeks along the "Muddy Missouri" River, landing every here and there to have a little brush with guerrillas who had fired on our boat from the banks or from secret recesses in the woods.
column3: On the old steamboat underscore War Eagle underscore, too, we paddled for weeks along the "Muddy Missouri" River, landing every here and there to have a little brush with guerrillas who had fired on our boat from the banks or from secret recesses in the woods.

column2: It was rare that we could catch them or have a real fight.
column3: It was rare that we could catch them or have a real fight.

column2: Their kind of war meant ambuscades and murder.
column3: Their kind of war meant ambuscades and murder.

column2: At last an end came to this dreadful guerrilla-chasing business in Missouri so far as we were concerned, anyway.
column3: At last an end came to this dreadful guerrilla chasing business in Missouri so far as we were concerned, anyway.

column2: We were to stop running after Price's ubiquitous army too.
column3: We were to stop running after Price's ubiquitous army too.

column2: We were no longer to be the victims of ambuscades and night riding murderers.
column3: We were no longer to be the victims of ambuscades and night riding murderers.

column2: The glad news came to my regiment that we were to be transferred to the South, where the real war was.
column3: The glad news came to my regiment that we were to be transferred to the South, where the real war was.

column2: One morning we left the cold and snow, where we had lived and shivered in thin tents all the winter, left the thankless duty of patrolling railroads in the storm at midnight, and marched in the direction of St. Louis.
column3: One morning we left the cold and snow, where we had lived and shivered in thin tents all the winter, left the thankless duty of patrolling railroads in the storm at midnight, and marched in the direction of saint Louis.

column2: A long, cold, miserable march it was too, hurrying in the daytime and freezing in our bivouacs in the snow and woods at night.
column3: A long, cold, miserable march it was too, hurrying in the daytime and freezing in our bivouacs in the snow and woods at night.

column2: Many a man we left to sicken and die at some farmhouse by the roadside.
column3: Many a man we left to sicken and die at some farmhouse by the roadside.

column2: Our destination was New Madrid, where we were to be a part of Pope's army in the siege and capture of that town.
column3: Our destination was New Madrid, where we were to be a part of Pope's army in the siege and capture of that town.

column2: As we were about to embark on boats at St. Louis we beheld in the snow and storm many steamers anchored out in the pitiless waters of the Mississippi River.
column3: As we were about to embark on boats at saint Louis we beheld in the snow and storm many steamers anchored out in the pitiless waters of the Mississippi River.

column2: These vessels were loaded with shivering thousands in gray and brown uniforms, the prisoners whom General Grant had captured at the battle of Fort Donelson.
column3: These vessels were loaded with shivering thousands in gray and brown uniforms, the prisoners whom General Grant had captured at the battle of Fort Donelson.

column2: There were twelve or fifteen thousand of them.
column3: There were twelve or fifteen thousand of them.

column2: Seeing this host of prisoners made us feel that at last the Union army had a general, although we had scarcely heard of U. S. Grant before.
column3: Seeing this host of prisoners made us feel that at last the Union army had a general, although we had scarcely heard of u s Grant before.

column2: This army of prisoners taken in battle was his introduction to the world.
column3: This army of prisoners taken in battle was his introduction to the world.

column2: Shortly we were before New Madrid, and the siege conducted by General Pope commenced.
column3: Shortly we were before New Madrid, and the siege conducted by General Pope commenced.

column2: The town was defended by strong forts and many cannon, but its speedy capture by us helped to open up the Mississippi River.
column3: The town was defended by strong forts and many cannon, but its speedy capture by us helped to open up the Mississippi River.

column2: It was a new experience to us, to have cannonballs come rolling right into our camp occasionally.
column3: It was a new experience to us, to have cannonballs come rolling right into our camp occasionally.

column2: Yet few men were injured by them.
column3: Yet few men were injured by them.

column2: We were in more danger when a fool officer one day took our brigade of infantry down through a cornfield to assault a gunboat that lay in a creek close by.
column3: We were in more danger when a fool officer one day took our brigade of infantry down through a cornfield to assault a gunboat that lay in a creek close by.

column2: The Rebel commander had expected us, and had his grape shot and his hot water hose, and such things all ready for us.
column3: The Rebel commander had expected us, and had his grape shot and his hot water hose, and such things all ready for us.

column2: We went out of that cornfield faster than we went in.
column3: We went out of that cornfield faster than we went in.

column2: This was real war, the thing my regiment had been so longing for, in place of chasing murderers and guerrillas in Missouri.
column3: This was real war, the thing my regiment had been so longing for, in place of chasing murderers and guerrillas in Missouri.

column2: We entered New Madrid one morning before daylight.
column3: We entered New Madrid one morning before daylight.

column2: The enemy had left in awful haste.
column3: The enemy had left in awful haste.

column2: I recall finding a dead Rebel officer, lying on a table in his tent, in full uniform.
column3: I recall finding a dead Rebel officer, lying on a table in his tent, in full uniform.

column2: He had been killed by one of our shells.
column3: He had been killed by one of our shells.

column2: A candle burned beside him, and his cold hands closed on a pencil note that said, "Kindly bury this unfortunate officer." His breakfast waited on a table in the tent, showing how unexpected was his taking off.
column3: A candle burned beside him, and his cold hands closed on a pencil note that said, "Kindly bury this unfortunate officer." His breakfast waited on a table in the tent, showing how unexpected was his taking off.

column2: Our victory was a great one for the nation, and it put two stars on the shoulder straps of General Pope.
column3: Our victory was a great one for the nation, and it put two stars on the shoulder straps of General Pope.

column2: It made him, too, commander of the Eastern army.
column3: It made him, too, commander of the Eastern army.

column2: A comrade in Company A of my regiment had been wounded a few days before and had died in the enemy's hands.
column3: A comrade in Company A of my regiment had been wounded a few days before and had died in the enemy's hands.

column2: I now found his grave.
column3: I now found his grave.

column2: At its head stood a board with this curious inscription: "This man says he was a private in the Fifth Iowa Regiment.
column3: At its head stood a board with this curious inscription: "This man says he was a private in the Fifth Iowa Regiment.

column2: He was killed while trying to attend to other people's business."
column3: He was killed while trying to attend to other people's business."

column2: Our command was now hurried to the Shiloh battlefield, of course too late to be of any use.
column3: Our command was now hurried to the Shiloh battlefield, of course too late to be of any use.

column2: But we took part in the long, wonderful, and ridiculous siege of Corinth, under Halleck, when our great army was held back by red tape, martinets, and the fear of a lot of wooden guns that sat on top of the enemy's breastworks, while that enemy, with all his men, and with all his guns, and bag and baggage, was escaping to the south.
column3: But we took part in the long, wonderful, and ridiculous siege of Corinth, under Halleck, when our great army was held back by red tape, martinets, and the fear of a lot of wooden guns that sat on top of the enemy's breastworks, while that enemy, with all his men, and with all his guns, and bag and baggage, was escaping to the south.

column2: Our deeds were no credit to anybody, though here and there we had a little fight.
column3: Our deeds were no credit to anybody, though here and there we had a little fight.

column2: One incident of great importance, however, happened to my regiment here. It was the death of our colonel.
column3: One incident of great importance, however, happened to my regiment here. It was the death of our colonel.

column2: One night when he was going the rounds of the picket lines out in the woods he was shot dead by one of our own men.
column3: One night when he was going the rounds of the picket lines out in the woods he was shot dead by one of our own men.

column2: The sentinel who did the killing declared that Rebels had been slipping up to his post all night, and when he would hail with "Who goes there?" they would fire at him and run into the darkness.
column3: The sentinel who did the killing declared that Rebels had been slipping up to his post all night, and when he would hail with "Who goes there?" they would fire at him and run into the darkness.

column2: He resolved to stand behind a tree the next time and fire without hailing.
column3: He resolved to stand behind a tree the next time and fire without hailing.

column2: By some accident Colonel Worthington and his adjutant were approaching this sentinel from the direction of the enemy.
column3: By some accident Colonel Worthington and his adjutant were approaching this sentinel from the direction of the enemy.

column2: Suddenly the sentinel held his gun around the tree and fired.
column3: Suddenly the sentinel held his gun around the tree and fired.

column2: The bullet struck the colonel in the forehead, killing him instantly.
column3: The bullet struck the colonel in the forehead, killing him instantly.

column2: As he fell from his horse the adjutant sprang to the ground and cried, "Who shot the officer of the day?" "I fired," exclaimed the sentinel, and he then told of his experiences of the night.
column3: As he fell from his horse the adjutant sprang to the ground and cried, "Who shot the officer of the day?" "I fired," exclaimed the sentinel, and he then told of his experiences of the night.

column2: He was arrested, tried, and acquitted.
column3: He was arrested, tried, and acquitted.

column2: Yet there were many among us who believed that the colonel had been intentionally murdered. He was one of the most competent colonels in the army, but among his soldiers he was fearfully unpopular.
column3: Yet there were many among us who believed that the colonel had been intentionally murdered. He was one of the most competent colonels in the army, but among his soldiers he was fearfully unpopular.

column2: He was, however, a splendid disciplinarian, but this was something the volunteers did not want.
column3: He was, however, a splendid disciplinarian, but this was something the volunteers did not want.

column2: In their minds the colonel had been only a petty tyrant, and not even wholly loyal.
column3: In their minds the colonel had been only a petty tyrant, and not even wholly loyal.

column2: With a different disposition he certainly would have been a distinguished soldier.
column3: With a different disposition he certainly would have been a distinguished soldier.

column2: He was one of the most military-looking men in the whole army, but friends he had none.
column3: He was one of the most military looking men in the whole army, but friends he had none.

column2: More than once his life had been threatened by soldiers who regarded themselves as having been treated badly by him.
column3: More than once his life had been threatened by soldiers who regarded themselves as having been treated badly by him.

column2: His body was brought into camp the next morning and lay in his tent in state.
column3: His body was brought into camp the next morning and lay in his tent in state.

column2: He was given a military funeral, and the horse that was bearing him when he was killed was led behind his coffin.
column3: He was given a military funeral, and the horse that was bearing him when he was killed was led behind his coffin.

column2: After his death numbers of the men of the regiment were indignant, when they found among his papers warrants and commissions intended by the governor for them, commissions that had never been delivered.
column3: After his death numbers of the men of the regiment were indignant, when they found among his papers warrants and commissions intended by the governor for them, commissions that had never been delivered.

column2: Their promotions had never come about.
column3: Their promotions had never come about.

column2: Now they knew why.
column3: Now they knew why.

column2: Worthington was succeeded by Colonel C. L. Matthies, one of the bravest, best, and most loved commanders of our army.
column3: Worthington was succeeded by Colonel c l Matthies, one of the bravest, best, and most loved commanders of our army.

column2: Later Matthies was made a general, and at the close of the war died of wounds received in battle.
column3: Later Matthies was made a general, and at the close of the war died of wounds received in battle.

column2: Although I was quartermaster sergeant of the regiment, I was always careful that this should not keep me away from the command when enduring hard marches or when engagements were coming on.
column3: Although I was quartermaster sergeant of the regiment, I was always careful that this should not keep me away from the command when enduring hard marches or when engagements were coming on.

column2: When in camp I kept my rifle in one of the ammunition wagons (of several of which I had charge), but if the alarm sounded my rifle was on my shoulder and I was the private soldier in the ranks of the company.
column3: When in camp one kept my rifle in one of the ammunition wagons (of several of which I had charge), but if the alarm sounded my rifle was on my shoulder and I was the private soldier in the ranks of the company.

column2: I deserved no special credit for this.
column3: I deserved no special credit for this.

column2: I was only doing my duty.
column3: I was only doing my duty.

column2: We had muzzle-loading Whitney rifles and bayonets.
column3: We had muzzle loading Whitney rifles and bayonets.

column2: The equipment and rations we carried in weight would have been a respectable load for a mule.
column3: The equipment and rations we carried in weight would have been a respectable load for a mule.

column2: CHAPTER III
column3: CHAPTER three

column2: Iuka, the fiercest battle of the war, 217 men out of 482 of my regiment are shot--The awful Rebel charge at Corinth--Moonlight on the battlefield--Bushels of arms and legs--Tombstones for fireplaces--One of Grant's mistakes.
column3: Iuka, the fiercest battle of the war, two hundred seventeen men out of four hundred eighty two of my regiment are shot-The awful Rebel charge at Corinth-Moonlight on the battlefield-Bushels of arms and legs-Tombstones for fireplaces-One of Grant's mistakes.
